docs.title: Let the Sims Begin
docs.text: Welcome to The Sims 4! The Sims 4 is a life simulation game where players create characters (sims) and control their day-to-day lives. Gameplay is open-ended with a variety of ways to play, including designing homes, fostering relationships, and choosing careers. There's no wrong way to play -- just have fun!

docs.title: About this Manual
docs.text:
This manual is meant to help new players get started and gain confidence by overviewing general applications of the game.

This guide overviews:

  • Create-A-Sim (CAS): Design sims and customize their traits, skills, aspirations, and appearance.
  • Build mode (BM): Build and decorate your sim’s home.
  • Live mode (LM): Manage needs, emotions, and lives of your sims.

This guide centers on PC controls. Here is a guide for Playstation and Xbox controls.

🗒️ NOTE: This guide is equipped with some beginner tips and cheat codes. These are not necessary for gameplay but are a great way to enhance your playing!

docs.title: Create-a-Sim
docs.text:
Whether you’re making yourself, your neighbor, or your celebrity crush, here's how you create a sim!

When starting in CAS, the game prompts you to pick to Create a Story or Start from Scratch.

Creating a story expedites the creation process by asking questions and assigning your sim traits, aspirations, and an appearance. If you’re unhappy with the outcome, everything is changeable. Saying, “No Thanks” to the story will drop you into customization. You can also download other players’ sims from the gallery.

docs.title: Traits and Aspirations
docs.text:
Traits are cornerstones of your sim’s personality, determining how they interact with their environment.

Traits are permanent once you finish your sim.

Aspirations function as your sim’s ultimate life goal.

Click the hexagons in the upper left of the screen to access traits and aspirations. Likes and dislikes, found beneath the panel, are best left unchosen, as your sim develops them in-game.

docs.title: Appearance
docs.text:
Appearance refers to the physical and biological aspects of your sim.

Click the diamond in the top left to alter a sim’s biology, including gender, age, voice, and relationship to other created sims.

Clicking on your sim opens the appearance wheel. Clicking different body parts provides different choices for clothing and body modifications.

Above the column listing clothing choices, there is a row of icons, each relating to a specific social setting. The type of clothing shown depends on the selected setting.

  • To the left of your sim, the two vertical sliders correspond to muscularity and weight.

💡TIP: If you want to precisely modify your sim, enter detail-edit-mode by clicking on the eyeglass icon to the left of your sim’s head.

Finally, give your sim a name in the top left corner. Click the checkmark in the bottom right, and you’re done!

docs.title: Controls
docs.text: Before you begin playing as your sim, let’s overview the controls for BM and LM. Camera controls in these modes are identical and are for trackpad and mouse unless otherwise noted.

docs.title: Camera Controls
docs.text:
• Moving the camera: Hold left click and drag, or use the WASD or arrow keys.
  • Readjusting camera angle: Hold right click and drag.
  • Zooming in/out: Use the scroll wheel on the mouse. For the trackpad, use two fingers in the middle and scroll up or down.
  • Tilting the camera: Hold down the scroll wheel on the mouse and move the whole mouse up and down. For the trackpad, hold down the command key and click the arrow keys.

docs.title: In-Game Controls
docs.text:
• Controlling time: Use the panel in the bottom middle of the screen to speed up, slow down, or pause time.
  • Moving between floors of a building: Click the up and down arrows in the top right.
  • Switching wall views (i.e. full, cutaway, no walls): Click the room icon in the top right.

docs.title: Build Mode
docs.text: So, you made your sim and are ready to release them into the world! But wait—they need a house first!

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
After exiting CAS, the game prompts you to pick a world to live in. It doesn’t matter which world you pick—your sim can always move later. Once you’ve selected your world, choose a lot to move your sim into.

Empty lots let you build your house with your remaining funds whereas built lots let you purchase a pre-furnished or unfurnished home. If you don’t like the layout, you can change it in BM; it’s completely customizable! (Just keep an eye on your funds).

🗒️ NOTE: Your sim’s household always starts with 20,000 Simoleons.

docs.title: Build Mode Features
docs.text:
Alright! You’ve bought your lot and moved in! The game drops your sim into LM, and you can’t modify your home from this mode. To access BM, click the hammer and wrench icon in the top right menu.

🗒️ NOTE: When you enter BM, your sim and time will pause.

Wow, that’s a lot of stuff on the screen! No worries, we detail each feature below.

docs.title: The Grid
docs.text:
There will be a white grid surrounding the floor of your lot. This is the buildable area, and the tiles that items will align to. It ensures the walls of your home and the items within don’t interrupt sims movements through the space.

To hide the grid, press G.

docs.title: The Tool Bar
docs.text:
The tool bar, at the top middle of the screen, holds these essential tools (from left to right):

  • Select
  • Eyedropper
  • Design
  • Sledgehammer
  • Undo and Redo
  • Save to Library
  • Move House
  • Bulldoze
    • Bulldoze Lot
    • Bulldoze Terrain
  • Time of day (only for simulating in BM)

For an in-depth look at these tools and other aspects of BM, see this BM Guide by the SimsWiki.

docs.title: Lot Info Panel
docs.text: The Lot Info Panel, at the top left of the screen, contains essential information about your lot, including lot type, dimensions, value, and traits and challenges.

docs.title: Build Buy Menu
docs.text:
The Build Buy Menu is the large panel at the bottom left of your screen with three categories. You can switch between categories by clicking on their respective icons flush to the left side of the menu.

  • Build Catalog (house icon): It’s the first tab opened when you enter BM, with a large interactive house image, and is the primary directory for items relevant to exterior decor and foundational building.
  • Objects-by-Room (chair-in-a-box icon): It brings up a large interactive image of a kitchen setting. To move between rooms, click the related icons located above the interactive image.
  • Objects-by-Function (single chair icon): It contains a drop down menu to select specific functions, like surface or plumbing.

💡TIP: You can resell any purchased item with the sledgehammer.

docs.title: Common Questions
docs.text:
There are many aspects to BM, so here are a few questions you might ask yourself as you’re exploring BM.

“I want to push this object against the wall, but the game won’t let me. Why?”

The game is particular about where items can go. To place objects without constraints, pull up the cheat window by pressing CTRL + Shift + C. In the pop-up bar, type “bb.moveobjects on” to place objects wherever. Check out this cheats guide for a longer, detailed explanation of available cheats and what they do.

💡TIP: Freely placing objects might impact their functionality. Play-test in LM when building with cheats.

“Woah, I just went down a floor level, and it’s really dark. What is this?”

Welcome to the basement! Basement levels function the same as your above-ground levels. It’s important to note that you must build a room in the basement level before you can place objects. Also, ensure you have a staircase otherwise your basement will be inaccessible!

“There’s an object in the world that I really like, but I can’t find it in BM. Why?”

The object is likely a part of the debug menu. Debug items are used in world, but not available for purchase in BM. However, using cheats lets you access these items for free in BM. See this debug guide for a better look at how to use it.

BM is one of the more complicated aspects of the game, but you’ll learn more features as you progress. Right now, this overview is a great start to familiarize yourself with the basics of BM.

To return to LM, click the two-people icon located in the top right menu.

docs.title: Live Mode
docs.text: You have your character and house, and now you’re ready to play as your sim! Here’s what to know about LM.

docs.title: Controlling Sims
docs.text:
Look at your beautiful sim! Uh-Oh, where are they? If you can’t find them in the world, left-click their portrait in the household panel. To follow them, right click their household portrait.

You can only control one sim at a time — switch between sims by left clicking their household portraits.

You aren’t just here to watch your sim — you’re here to play as them!

  • Click on sims in the world to see available interactions with them.
  • Your sim's actions will queue in the order you choose them, and the icons appear in the bottom left corner.
  • Some actions continue until you tell your sim to stop by left clicking the action icon.

  • Actions with the orange circle are instant actions done by the player.

  • When your sim leaves a location without you following them, their household portrait grays out. Click the two-person icon in their portrait to see available actions.

🗒️ NOTE: Around each action icon will be a progress circle, showing time until completion.

docs.title: Needs
docs.text:
What do we want? Needs! When do we want them? Now!

The Needs tab is in the Utility Panel (UP) at the bottom right of the screen. Based on a sim’s needs, they will gain moodlets that determine their emotional state, displayed under their character portrait. Moodlets result from actions, events, and in-game experiences.

  • To satisfy a sim’s needs, queue actions related to the specific need.
    • Ex. Have them eat to satisfy their hunger.
  • If you fail to satisfy a sim’s needs, there may be consequences.
    • If they are too tired, they may faint!

docs.title: Wants and Aspirations
docs.text:
You chose an aspiration for your sim when you made them, and to see the tasks to complete it, click the gold icon in the UP.

💡TIP: Completing the aspiration allows you to pick a new one for your sim and grants them a longer lifespan!

Wants are the thought bubbles above your sim's character portrait. There are no consequences for not fulfilling these or aspirations.

  • Wants go away on their own unless you pin them by clicking the pushpin near them.
  • Completing a want or aspiration grants you aspiration points.
    • To spend these, go to the Aspiration tab and click “Rewards Store.”
  • The Rewards Store has items and traits you may purchase for the selected sim.

docs.title: Skills
docs.text:
Some wants and aspirations involve learning skills!

  • Your sim’s skills and their levels are under the Skills tab in the UP.

    • Don’t fret if this is blank! BM contains items that increase skills, or your sim can purchase a book on a skill.
      • To buy a book, click on any bookshelf.

  • Reaching higher levels of skills unlocks new abilities.

  • When your sim does a skill-increasing action, a bar appears above their head to show skill progress.
    • Most skill actions will only stop when you cancel the action.

💡TIP: The Handiness skill is obtained through fixing items. If your sim attempts to fix an electronic after already being electrocuted by it, they will die on the second attempt. Save your game before fixing electronics with a low Handiness skill!

Some skills and their objects include Comedy (microphone), Gaming (computer), and Painting (easel). Check out this list of skills your sim can achieve.

docs.title: Careers
docs.text:
Let’s get to work! If you don’t want a traditional career for your sim, they can use skills for profit, such as selling paintings or publishing books.

Want a 9-5? Click the Career tab, the briefcase icon in the UP, to find a job!

Once you select a career, you can find your sim’s progress towards a promotion and their work schedule in the Career tab.

  • Jobs have tasks to do before every shift if you want your sim to progress faster in their career.
  • Sims will go to work on their own. If you cancel the action, send them to work by clicking “Go to Work” in the Career tab.
    • Being late or missing work will lower your sim's work performance; if their performance is too low, they’ll be demoted.

Clicking the two-person icon on a household portrait provides actions for your sim at work that will affect their performance. Working hard increases a sim’s work performance while socializing increases relationships. Hover over the different options to see details.

docs.title: Relationships
docs.text:
Your sim is flourishing. A job, skills, and a house—now all they need are some friends!

  • When you interact with a sim, a bar at the top of the screen shows your sim’s relationship with them.
    • Green is friendship, pink is romance, red is dislike.

Interactions will affect the relationship progression differently depending on the conversational likes of the sim you’re interacting with.

  • Ex. When Mischief interactions are performed on a sim that dislikes Mischief, friendship will decrease.

💡TIP: When romance is low with another sim, bold romantic interactions, like a pick-up line, are unlikely to succeed.

docs.title: Events and Traveling
docs.text:
Events are one of many features that allow you to meet other sims. The first event you encounter is the Welcome Wagon.

  • The Welcome Wagon prompts your sim’s neighbors to come meet you, their new neighbor!
    • Your neighbors will bring a fruitcake as a gift. The fruitcake is infamous in the Sims community. Don’t let your sim eat it or they’ll gain an uncomfortable moodlet for the rest of the day.

For all events, like the Welcome Wagon, there will be an icon and panel in the top left corner.

  • If you complete the tasks for an event, your sim may receive a reward.

💡TIP: Not all events will have tasks. If your sim is invited to an event, there will be no tasks to complete.

  • If you wish to end an event early, click the timer icon in the event panel.

Events include dates, parties, weddings, and more. You can start an event by using the phone located below the character portrait.

Traveling is another way to get out and meet other sims. To travel, click on your sim or phone and find the “travel” button.

  • You will be given the choice to travel alone or with other sims!
  • When traveling to another sim’s house, their icon will be translucent if they’re not home and opaque if they are.
  • Click the home icon on a sim’s household portrait to send them home.
  • You will have to do this for each sim in your household that you want to send home if they are traveling together.

docs.title: Wrapping Up
docs.text: And that’s it! The rest of your gameplay is up to you. Remember, there are no wrong ways to play. Have fun!
